EDVISIT^92819461^STEPHENSON, BREDNA^07/15/86^WALLACE, VELMA
I saw this patient on 07/15/2086 in conjunction with Dr. Echols.
I confirm that I have interviewed and examined the patient,
reviewed the resident's documentation on the patient's chart, and
discussed the evaluation, plan of care, and disposition with the
patient.
CHIEF COMPLAINT: A 68-year-old female with leg pain.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient with known coronary
artery disease, peripheral vascular disease, and diabetes, status
post left fem-pop bypass and transmetatarsal amputation of her
left foot at the Siouxland on 05/02/2086. This was complicated by
acute renal failure with creatinine between 1.6 and 2.4 and
labile sugars. She was discharged to rehab on 04/19/2086 for
approximately 1 month. Subsequently, she developed left thigh
erythema, swelling, and pain along the incision site yesterday.
She has had no fevers, nausea, or vomiting but has had difficulty
ambulating due to pain, denies any diarrhea but has had some mild
stomach upset.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Remarkable as I said for hypertension,
diabetes, CHF, chronic renal insufficiency, peripheral vascular
disease, and hypothyroidism. She had MIBI in 2084 with LAD and
D1 lesion. Her EF was 35%. She had a CABG in 2083.
Social history, family history, and review of systems are as per
the written note.
MEDICATIONS: Amitriptyline, atenolol, aspirin,
hydrochlorothiazide, insulin, Lasix, lisinopril, Norvasc,
Synthroid, Zocor, and Zoloft.
ALLERGIES: None.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: The patient is awake and alert, in no
acute distress, however, distinctly uncomfortable. Vital signs:
Temperature is 97.2, pulse 59, respiratory rate 20, blood
pressure 148/67, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. For
full physical exam findings, please see the resident's written
note. Specifically, HEENT, neck, abdominal exam, and neurologic
exams are within normal limits as documented. Respiratory exam
reveals crackles at the bases but no respiratory distress.
Cardiovascular exam: Regular rate and rhythm with 2/6 systolic
ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border.
Musculoskeletal exam: The fem-pop incision on the left leg is
concerning for purulent drainage along the incision site,
especially along the upper aspect of the upper thigh. There is
approximately an area of 8 x 5 cm of erythema, induration, and
tenderness surrounding the area draining purulent material. The
patient also has a transmetatarsal amputation. The wound there
is clean, dry, and intact.
LABORATORY DATA: CBC and electrolytes remarkable for white blood
count of 10.9, BUN and creatinine ratio of 30:1.4 respectively.
EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT COURSE: Surgery was consulted regarding
this likely wound infection. Vancomycin, levofloxacin, and
Flagyl were their request for antibiotics. These were
administered in the Emergency Department, and the patient will be
admitted for likely operative debridement of this wound
infection.
******** Not reviewed by Attending Physician ********
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS: Postsurgical infection.
SECONDARY DIAGNOSIS: Diabetes.
TERTIARY DIAGNOSIS: Peripheral vascular disease.
DISPOSITION: Admitted.
